name: Monitoring with Amazon CloudWatch
description: Covers the fundamentals and benefits of monitoring AWS resources using Amazon CloudWatch.

cards.front: Your EC2-hosted web application experiences performance degradation at peak hours. You want to track CPU spikes and set alerts. Which AWS service should you use?
cards.back: Use Amazon CloudWatch to monitor CPU utilization metrics, set alarms for thresholds, and take automated actions to mitigate performance issues.
cards.example: A CloudWatch alarm triggers an Auto Scaling policy when CPU utilization exceeds 80% for 5 minutes.
cards.subject: Monitoring on AWS

cards.front: An operations team wants to detect unusual access patterns and traffic spikes to improve security posture. What AWS feature enables this?
cards.back: Monitoring metrics over time builds a baseline, allowing you to detect anomalies like unusual traffic or IP addresses. CloudWatch enables setting alarms and triggering actions based on anomalies.
cards.example: Detecting unexpected access from foreign IPs to an S3 bucket based on baseline traffic patterns.
cards.subject: Monitoring on AWS

cards.front: Your business wants to know if users are adopting a new feature in your application. How can monitoring help with this?
cards.back: Application-level monitoring allows collection of usage metrics that reveal how many users interact with a new feature, enabling data-driven business decisions.
cards.example: Tracking daily active users who click a new 'Upload Cat Photo' feature through custom metrics.
cards.subject: Monitoring on AWS

cards.front: How does Amazon CloudWatch help improve cost-efficiency in AWS resource usage?
cards.back: By monitoring resource utilization, CloudWatch helps identify underused resources so you can rightsize instances and reduce costs.
cards.example: CloudWatch reveals an EC2 instance has consistent CPU usage under 10%, prompting a downgrade to a smaller instance type.
cards.subject: Monitoring on AWS

cards.front: What is a metric in the context of AWS monitoring, and how is it useful?
cards.back: A metric is a time-ordered set of data points related to a specific resource or application. Monitoring metrics helps detect issues and optimize system performance.
cards.example: Monitoring 'NetworkIn' and 'CPUUtilization' metrics for an EC2 instance to detect heavy load patterns.
cards.subject: Monitoring on AWS

cards.front: What are some key benefits of monitoring AWS workloads using Amazon CloudWatch?
cards.back: Monitoring enables early detection of operational issues, improved system performance, enhanced security, data-driven decisions, and cost optimization.
cards.example: Proactively scaling an Auto Scaling group when CloudWatch detects a CPU utilization spike.
cards.mnemonic: RISEC – Reliability, Insights, Security, Efficiency, Cost
cards.subject: Monitoring on AWS
